trans-unit.source: Choose a form approach to explore:
Forms using template directives and two-way binding
Forms using FormControl, FormGroup, and reactive patterns
Forms using Angular signals for state management
View the slideshow presentation about Angular forms
Forms using FormControl, FormGroup, FormArray, and reactive patterns with advanced validation
Name must be at least 2 characters
Password must be at least 8 characters
Password must contain uppercase, lowercase, number, and special character
Forms using template directives and two-way binding with dynamic features
Angular provides two approaches for handling user input through forms:
Forms where the logic is defined in the template
Forms where the logic is defined in the component
The new approach using Angular signals
Today we'll explore all three approaches and see their differences!
Uses [(ngModel)] for automatic synchronization between form controls and component properties
Form validation and logic is defined directly in the template using directives
Quick to implement for simple forms with minimal boilerplate code
Angular automatically creates and manages the form state behind the scenes
Uses Angular signals for reactive form state management with automatic change detection
Cleaner, more intuitive API compared to traditional reactive forms
Optimized change detection with fine-grained reactivity using signals
Modern approach that aligns with Angular's signal-based architecture
